name: Parsed Rastafarian
description:
This small scale tensegrity is meant more for display than to play. The elastic string allows movements among the struts, and maintains the shape when handled. The basic tetrahedral geometry prevents that the structure can collapse in itself like the octahedral models.

The model can balance on each of its corners, and the three different colours outline the tetrahedral structure in surprising ways.

name: Nippon
description: This tensegrity octahedron is made of bamboo and elastic string. The colour combination resembled me of the rising sun in the Japanese flag. It has a robust bounce way and weighs only about 30 grams. The models collapses in three ways, creating different pattern each way. With a size of 20x20x20cm it fits nicely on a desktop or book shelf, and the little weight makes it well suited for hanging installations. But then you couldn't play with it anymore..... All models for sale are hand made in Brunswick, a suburb of Melbourne. Find out more about 'You can touch this!' in my blog.

name: The Affordable Tensegrity Toolkit
description: The Affordable Tensegrity Toolkit (TATT) allows anyone to experience to build a tensegrity structure. It contains standard components that have been tested for easy assembly, dis- and reassembly. Depending on the size chosen (starter - 12 elements, standard - 32 elements) many geometric shapes can be build. The toolkit is accompanied by video and photo instructions that can found on my blog.
